Starting for last couple of release, STS is very slow in building projects and keeps for running background activities. Eclipse on the other hand is much faster.

I have multiple project on my workspace which are dependent on each other. Let me know if you need any logs.

I'm using STS 3.9.1. 
Let it be Navigator view or Project Explorer view or Package Explorer view, If I click on a file, it opens in the same window rather than the code editor window.

Look at the "SignUpIncomplete...java" file where it has been opened. It should have been among other java files that are opened in a window.

issues.title: management.trace.include in application.properties does not auto-complete as expected
issues.body:
Using STS 3.9.2 with a Spring Boot 1.5.9.RELEASE, auto-completion of `management.trace.include` in `application.properties` does not work as I would expect.

If I type `management.trace.i`, wait for the single auto-completion suggestion to appear, and then press enter, the result is `management.trace.include.`. I expected the result to be `management.trace.include=`. If I correct the `.` to be `=`, I would then expect to receive suggestions for the value and for those suggestions to be based on the `Include` enum. The actual behaviour is that no suggestions are made.

issues.title: STS 3.9.1: RequestMapping View shows all the Resource URL with the same / value

issue_comments.body:
Hello @garyrussell 

>Did you enable "Spring Nature" on the project?

No, I didn't. Now works fine. Thank you.  

> For historical reasons, some of the original SI schemas on the internet are outdated; we can't change them without possibly breaking (admittedly very old) user applications.

I am confused about that, I thought the `.xsd` files should be referenced through the .jar files from SI by itself through the `META-INF/spring.schemas` configuration 

> See the IMPORTANT note near the top of this one.
Thanks by that link. Here two things:

- Is that note shared in the SI Reference Documentation?
- The link shared within the note is broken.

> If you enable Spring Nature on the project, STS knows how to find the proper schema in the spring jars > (there is special mapping in META-INF/spring.schemas).

Yes. I have confirmed that. 

Thanks a lot!.

issues.title: STS Crash after project spring version upgrade 3 -> 4
issues.body:
Our application was using spring version 3.2.3.RELEASE and we decided to migrate it to 4.0.9.RELEASE.

After the upgrade we were unable to ever use STS again. When launch the workspace, STS stops responding after some time (5-30 min).

We tried downloading a STS new version (3.9.x), creating new workspaces, disabling all validations. Nothing worked so far but if we use a regular eclipse version we have no problems at all.

Let me know what you need to assist you in solving this problem.

issues.title: AOP pointcut validation bug.
Impossible to save files after edit of AspectJ pointcut
issues.body:
After first edit of aspectj pointcut following file saves are not possible. Files not related to aspectj config are not saved as well. Initially UI was blocked by pop-up with 20 running threads related to "Remote Systems", but I was able to turn it off. Now UI is frozen for a minute with "Waiting user operation". Sometimes IDE is become usable again by itself, but usually I have to kill the process.
As well there is a lot of exceptions in log like attached one: [error.log](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/files/1446961/error.log)

Is it possible to turn off any AspectJ support from preferences? Or uninstall some plug-in from STS responsible for it.

issues.title: STS 3.9.0 is much slower than previous STS 3.8.x
issues.body:
The following elapsed time measurements were taken on Windows 10 on an AMD Phenom II X4 920 Processor 2.80 GHz processor with 8GB of ram and STS installed on solid state disks.  STS.ini uses the following to start STS:

```
-vm
C:/Program Files/Java/jdk1.8.0_131/bin/javaw.exe
-startup
plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_1.4.0.v20161219-1356.jar
--launcher.library
plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.win32.win32.x86_64_1.1.500.v20170531-1133
-product
org.springsource.sts.ide
--launcher.defaultAction
openFile
-vmargs
-Dosgi.requiredJavaVersion=1.8
-Xms40m
-Dosgi.module.lock.timeout=10
-Xverify:none
-Dorg.eclipse.swt.browser.IEVersion=10001
-Xmx1200m
```
The first number is the elapsed time in seconds (or minutes:seconds) since the previous bullet or since the start of the test.  Three separate tests were run. For example, in the next test, the progress bar started updating 32.6 seconds after the workspace name was entered. The STS window appeared 7.1 seconds after the progress bar started updating.
# new workspace called wsp1
* 0 - enter wsp1 in workspace dialog
* 32.6 - start of progress bar on splash screen
* 7.1 - window appears
* 21.6 - dashboard is updated

# open existing blank ws wsp1
* 5.9 - select workspace dialog
* 1:11.5 - start of progress bar on splash screen
* 8.9 - window appears
* 13.7 - dashboard is updated

# restart existing wsp1
* 1:20.9 - start of progress bar on splash screen
* 6.6 - window appears
* 14.1 - dashboard updated

# switch to existing ws with 9 maven java projects 
* 1:33.7 - start of progress bar on splash screen
* 17.3 - window appears

These times are really not acceptable.  I chose this tests because they do not require test projects or data.

I strongly suspect that the issue is with the eclipse m2e plugin, not the maven-dependency-plugin as I am able to perform the copy operation when invoking maven itself.  The error is not always there.  It seems to always re-appear after a Maven/Update Project (alt-F5) menu command.
Please make sure you create the appropriate ticket with the m2e plugin group and do not just close this ticket (because the problem does not lie in the Spring STS code).  Please update this ticket with the m2e ticket number.

issue_comments.body: Actually, I found out where the m2e connector for the Maven Dependency Plugin is and created [issue 19](https://github.com/ianbrandt/m2e-maven-dependency-plugin/issues/19) for this problem.
Kris please do not close the ticket. STS uses the connector and STS is affected. Not only is it affected but you should be following up also on issue 19

issues.title: Eclipse UI Thread freezes while Spring IDE Plugin creates Hyperlinks
issues.body:
I have >100 interdependent Maven/Spring projects in my workspace (~1.400.000 LOC) with hundrets of XML bean config files. When I open a class located in higher tier project (indirectly depends on >50 of the other projects) and press Ctrl (to access a context menu or to copy code via Ctrl+C) Eclipse freezes for 3s to 39s depending on which plugins are installed.

It originates from `org.springframework.ide.eclipse.quickfix.hyperlinks.AutowireHyperlinkDetector.addHyperlinks` (_see attached thread dumps created by Eclipse's built in monitoring_). It is reproducable with STS or an Eclipse for Java Developers with Spring IDE (just core) added.

Removing the Spring IDE completely solves the issue.

[eclipse_ui_freeze.log](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/files/1435632/eclipse_ui_freeze.log)
[eclipse_ui_freeze_1.log](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/files/1435633/eclipse_ui_freeze_1.log)

issues.title: Shared microservice cloud for local integration tests
issues.body:
We develop above 100 microservices - monthly increasing - in 7 teams and therefore its completely impossible to run integration tests (based on feature branches of single teams or developers ) locally/offline on a dev machine- it would exceed available machine ressources (mostly ram,). 
Therefore a developer/team would like to fallback to reuse the stable running microservices in the cloudfoundry shared via org>space with his/other teams. Here the developer will e.g. have access to the last integrated stable release train of all microservices. 
Running one of these microserviceslocally with commits a head on a feature branch, the developer would like to run integrations tests through the cloudfoundry deployed stable microservices, but as soon as the requests comes to usage of any of his locally running services - the discovery lookup shall find and route towards the mciroservice instance on his local machine only for his request. Of course integration test requests of other developers will never be routed to any dev machine else them their own.

**The solution for such scenario could be like this:**

Prerequisite for all microservices(locally and deployed on the cloudfoundry space all share together) is a (new  artifact) "Spring Cloud devtools" dependency, because this one brings in the auto configuration for this dev features for the cloud in Spring Boot and Spring Cloud Netflix - optional.

The Spring Cloud devtools provide an following new behavior to spring components:

1.) In STS Boot Dashboard a developer can tie/register a local microservice to a cloudfoundry space where spring cloud services are being deployed and therefore its possible to register the local instance to the remote registry(eureka).  
2.) The local instance is registered with special eureka metadata "localdevroute" (added on the fly by a Spring Cloud devtools 2.) enhanced DiscoveryClient marking the instance as devtools instance for the cloudfoundry the developers cloudfoundry user name (exactly reuse the one known to STS boot dashboard the the local ms i tied to).

3.) For any Spring Cloud STS project which has configured such Spring Cloud devtools integration a @SpringBootTest will add  a pcf-user header param "localdevroute" to any test request (if not already attached) that has the value of the developers cloudfoundry username.

4.) Spring cloud Netflix DiscoveryClient (Ribbon) will  extract the request header parama "localdevroute" and match it against microservice metadata attribute "localdevroute", and will filter down to these instances for the following load balancing decision only. If no match is found the complete instance list will be used as usual. There already is github project (we use for simlar things) that provide such feature tbased on PredicateRules in o Ribbon. see https://jmnarloch.wordpress.com/2015/11/25/spring-cloud-ribbon-dynamic-routing/

issues.title: spring nature is not added on maven project import for project with spring-boot-starter-parent
issues.body:
STS 3.8.4

Although i have "spring-boot-starter-parent" downstram in my <parent> pom "inheritance" of my project being imported, STS does not automatically add the spring nature on "import existing maven project". Therfore the project also does not show up in spring explorer and spring boot dashboard. From what i remember that worked once and should work out of the box, based on m2e detection of spring boot deps, shouldn't it?

As i have about 100 microservices being manged in a git project via submodules, it would be a hell to tweak every project by mouse and/or manually edit .project files. In fact we don't want to check in .project files also.

issues.title: "Oracle alike" plugin for Spring IDE (Eclipse) to create Spring ORM classes
issues.body:
(migrated from https://jira.spring.io/browse/STS-4364)

Dear,

Oracle OEPE [Kepler 12.1.2.1|http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/developer-tools/eclipse/downloads/oepe-12121-1981534.html] includes Spring IDE. To better integrate Spring IDE into Kepler Oracle has developed an additional tiny but super useful plugin called "Oracle Spring Tools".

Very soon Oracle dropped plugin stating: "Oracle Enterprise Pack for Eclipse 12.1.2.2 no longer depends on Spring IDE” - which was other way of saying, we don't care... Being their big client we could try asking to have it back - but - wouldn't it be better that this little plugin is part of IDE and available to whole community and not only OEPE users… I am sure you could make this wizard better and more complete than the one from Oracle.

Plugin analyses all @Entity classes and takes into account relationships, then it provides UI to get desired names of packages, Spring Services, Dao Repositories. Finally developer decides about grouping, meaning, which Entities are handled by particular DAO. Result is: several Spring services and DAOs with hundreds of persist, update, find, search functions inside each.

This all above can be done after JPA wizard creates entities from tables - and allows us to create whole API in a day. This process saves us days or even weeks (we have hundreds nicely normalized related tables in DB) and we get perfect DAOs and Services and from here on we add our own special functions that will handle our own named queries and additional stuff… but this is great starting point.

Sorry for lengthy post, and my apologies that I have assumed that plugin originally came from Eclipse IDE on the market space where I asked original question. If you wish more info, I can provide tutorials I have written, just please contact me to get my RL email.

Many thanks for reading.

issues.title: Spring IDE eats keyboard shortcuts in Neon
issues.body:
(migrated from https://jira.spring.io/browse/IDE-1390)

The problem can be reproduced as follows:

1. Install a clean version of Neon Eclipse (I did the zip install if that matters; I'm on windows 7, but didn't use the new msi install)
2. Create a java project and a java source file
3. Verify that the keyboard shortcuts ctrl-d (delete line), ctrl-alt-up/down (duplicate line(s)) and alt-up/down (move line(s)) all work.
4. Go to marketplace and search for spring;
5. Install the 3.8.1 spring ide with the default suggestions (i.e., everything but roo).
6. Reboot eclipse as suggested.
7. Verify that the ctrl-d, ctrl-alt-up/down and alt-up/down no longer work. They do nothing. It's as if Spring IDE is swallowing the keystrokes and not doing anything with them (including not passing them to the eclipse java editor).

Interestingly, if you create a groovy file or a yml file, the keyboard shortcuts do work even after the spring ide install. the problem seems to be unique to java files.
Also, if you uninstall all of the spring ide plugins, the problem does not go away. You have to delete the .metadata directory. So, there's some shadow of the spring ide install left even after an uninstall.

issues.title: History of searches in Quick Text Search
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4397)

It would be really nice to have a history of recent searches that have been done with the "Quick Text Search". It often happens to me that I search for something, jump to a result, edit something and re-open the "Quick Text Search" to go to the next occurence. If I now have something selected in the editor, the search term is replaced by the current selection and I need to go and find the previous search term again.
The history of search queries could be accessible via a combobox like in the normal "Find/Replace" dialog.
The  button to clear the query could be removed IMHO because the query is pre-selected if you open the Quick Text Search dialog so that the current query can be easily cleared by just starting to type.
Pressing the down arrow should open the combox list to select a previous query.

issues.title: Ability to open multiple results at once in the Quick Search Eclipse plugin
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4402)

When searching for a term you usually have multiple results showing up in the view below the search query field. In this results view you can click a result and see the matching lines of code in the details view below. And if you want to open the actual file, you just press enter or double click a result.
All fine and nice, but in my experience you often need to make similar changes across a set of source files, and in this case it would be great if one could shift-click multiple result lines and open all those files in the editor at once. Right now you have to repeat the search (oh and remember what the search term was!) and get the next result.
I hope it is possible to implement this without too much effort.

issues.title: YAML editor does not accept user-defined templates
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4266, please check for additional comments)

When you CTRL-SPACE in a Spring YAML file you only get Spring proposals for completion. It would be handy to be able to define one's own templates as well, and there is an Eclipse feature for this (it seems) but it only applies to "Yedit" files.

issues.title: Buildship support for projects / natures
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4271)

In 3.7.2 we add spring-ature to buildship project as part of our wizards import strategy. But this has the drawback the nature is not going to be added if project is imported in another way.
Recently had a chat with Etienne S from Gradleware. He mentioned there may be a better way to deal with adding natures/builders, even though they do not provide a 'project confgrator' mechanism.
Should look into that. There are two possible paths to explore:

- checkout changes in tooling api for version 2.9 and a few ones before that supposedly it provides something that may help
- maybe explore if this could be fixed via the spring-boot gradle plugin (i.e. make the plugin add the nature / builder)

issues.title: filter stack traces based on customizable list of prefixes
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4272, please check for additional comments)

Thomas Darimont brought up this idea of filtering stack traces to avoid scrolling through thousands of lines.
He did something like this:
https://gist.github.com/thomasdarimont/0d34d218c958fb6e4a76
Maybe we can add this as a feature to the console view, including a preference to customize those prefixes, so that people could even add their own specific prefixes to the list of hidden stack trace elements.

issues.title: Quick Search - ability to run in background
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4282)

The Quick Search opens a Modal popup that blocks the page.
I find this disruptive and think it would be better if the page did not get blocked so that users can continue to work while the search window is shown.

issues.title: Quick Search - Search results window should not close
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4283)

Upon double clicking on a search result entry, the search result window closes.
If i want to see multiple results i have to rerun the search.
Would be nice if the window stayed open and/or have a next/previous button, so i should be able to navigate between search results entries.

issues.title: ignore beans from libraries when doing validation
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4309)

We should consider to ignore Spring beans when doing validation that are being contributed by libraries. It doesn't make much sense to report a problem or an error on those beans, since there is not much people can do about that if the bean is being defined in a library.
This would improve build times.

issues.title: Add starters to existing gradle build file
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4310)

The New->Spring Starter Project is great for getting started with a Spring Boot application, but if you don't select all of the starter dependencies you need before generating the project, you must go back and manually add them to your build.gradle file.
It would be nice if, when editing a build.gradle file there were a tab or some other mechanism that listed all of the available starter dependencies with checkboxes, giving you the choice to add them to the dependencies list without having to manually type them in.
This is basically the same as STS-4242, but for Gradle build files.

issues.title: add a scrollbar to the preview textbox in the "Quick Text Search" dialog
issues.body: (migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4344)

issues.title: Implement Search History for the Quick Search Eclipse plugin
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4384)

I use the Quick Search plugin a lot, in fact it has become somewhat indispensible for me. So thanks for creating this useful plugin.
What I think the plugin needs is a way to remember the previous 10 or so searches. Something simple, like a little down-arrow out to the right in the search input field, that would fold out to reveal the search history.
I think this would be very handy since one typically jumps around in the codebase a few times while identifying an issue or implementing a fix of some kind.

issues.title: Disable bean validation on a single XML file - or fix Spring profile validation
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-3885)

When using bean profiles, any XML elements that reside within multiple profiles are marked as an error during validation. I understand that one could be running two profiles, so in theory it could be invalid at runtime. In many cases, this is not the case. Runtime execution is fine, it just has an error in the project due to the validation.
Being able to turn off XML validation of duplicate entries within a single XML file will allow for better use of spring profiles along with keeping the benefit of validation in other places.
Here is an example of one that would be in error during validation but not at runtime, even if execution environment is only set at a single profile:

```
<beans profile="security-ad">
<security:global-method-security>
<security:protect-pointcut access="ROLE_THAT_ROLE" expression="execution(* com.test.service.TestServiceImpl.testSecuredMethod(..))"/>
</security:global-method-security>
</beans>
<beans profile="security-tam">
<security:global-method-security>
<security:protect-pointcut access="ROLE_THIS_ROLE" expression="execution(* com.test.service.TestServiceImpl.testSecuredMethod(..))"/>
</security:global-method-security>
</beans>
<beans profile="security-embedded">
<security:global-method-security>
<security:protect-pointcut access="ROLE_ADMIN" expression="execution(* com.test.service.TestServiceImpl.testSecuredMethod(..))"/>
</security:global-method-security>
</beans>
```

Please take a look at my stackoverflow question for a description of the issue: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30590661/why-does-sts-warn-me-about-non-matching-parameters/30592753

issues.title: Create Eclipse Oomph Installer
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4161, please take a look for additional comments)

As a developer, I'd like to be able to use the Oomph installer to install STS. Additionally, I'd like to be able to copy the STS oomph setup configuration and modify it for my organization (adding additional plugins and other setup that might not be done in the stock STS install).

issues.title: Set debug breakpoints in spring integration flow xml/graphical editor
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4189)

To find errors in spring integration message flows defined as xml configuration debugging is required.
But debugging of spring integration message flows can be very hard because it is difficult to find the corresponding spring implementation location for the xml namespace element to set a breakpoint.
For this it would be great to have the ability to set a breakpoint directly on a specific namespace element in xml or graphical representation in STS editor and STS sets the breakpoint automatically on a suitable entry point for corresponding implementation class. For example in the message dispatcher entry point for a message channel or at the transform entry point of a payload transformer.

issues.title: Out-of-the-box STS can't import Spring Framework
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4215, please take a look for more comments)

The Spring Framework cannot be cleanly imported into a fresh install of STS, due to both missing features (Gradle, Groovy-Eclipse) and, apparently, some configuration steps that I haven't been able to entirely figure out.
I know that the Groovy support was previously the realm of the discontinued GGTS, but as Spring itself is now built on Gradle and uses Groovy in its codebase, it seems to me that STS should have the wherewithal to handle the import walkthrough in the Spring repo.

issues.title: replace javafx web rendering with embedded SWT browser again
issues.body: at the moment the dashboard uses JavaFX technology (and its SWT integration/bridge) to render the dashboard main page. We should replace this with the SWT embedded browser widget again, since it has improved on the various platforms. This should help us to reduce the technological complexity.

issues.title: Improve Spring Security Java Config Formatting
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4064, please take a look for additional comments)

I'm wondering if the STS team can help with builder API formatting.
This can be pretty generic request, but this is focussed on how Spring Security's Java Config gets formatted. There is a detailed blog post here.
A few ideas:

- Automatically enable the no-format support
- Automatically include the no-format tags around methods that have an argument that implements SecurityBuilder (i.e. HttpSecurity)
- A more advanced option might be to enable the code formatter to format the code correctly.

issues.title: take included annotations into account for Spring java config searches
issues.body: At the moment the search for Spring java config classes is based on the Java search index and searches for a list of concrete annotations. Embedded or included annotations are not taken into account. We need to change this in order to take those included annotations into account automatically.

issues.title: invalid derived query doesn't work with concatenated types in generics
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4081, please take a look for additional old comments)

The new 3.6.4.RELEASE seems to have a small regression. 
For the following repository definition using multiple generic parameters:
```
interface IDao<T extends IEntity & INamable> extends ...
   Page<T> findByName(final String name, final Pageable pageable);

```
It incorrectly detects the following problem:
`Invalid derived query! No property name found for type IEntity!`
It seems to only evaluate the first generic param (IEntity and ignore the second one). If I switch the parameters and have the INameable first - the error goes away.

issues.title: Improve accuracy of 'is boot app' test
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4421)

Boot dashboard is showing applications which are not spring boot applications. 
These are Maven modules which gives jar file at the end but for library.
I suspect one thing: Those modules have a common dependency on 'spring-boot-starter-logging'.
Could you have a look ?

(additional old comments at https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4421)

issues.title: bean constructor argument validator erroneously checks abstract beans
issues.body:
(migrated from https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4435)

Create a minimal Spring project.
Add the following 2 beans in a bean definition xml file:

```
<!-- This is an abstract bean, the constructor argument count validator should not report a problem, but it does -->
<bean id="abstractParent" class="java.util.Date" abstract="true">
<constructor-arg index="0" value="1" />
<constructor-arg index="1" value="1" />
</bean>
<bean parent="abstractParent">
<constructor-arg index="2" value="1" />
</bean>

```

The validator complained on the abstractParent bean that java.util.Date doesn't have a 2-argument constructor even though that bean definition is abstract.

Feel free to comment on this with thoughts and ideas... :-)

issue_comments.body: Hey Olli! Can we use a release version of the spring-data-commons project? It would make legal approval easier for all the other projects that are consuming and shipping Spring IDE. Any chance to do this or do you need the latest bits and pieces?

As mentioned in https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-3780?focusedCommentId=101174 changing the import-package into a required-bundle dependency causes other issues. This is true for the org.eclipse.core.runtime bundle as well as the org.eclipse.m2e.maven.runtime bundle. The maven runtime bundle exports too many other packages as well, which can cause a package-use conflict. The history of the MANIFEST.MF file of the spring-ide maven bundle shows quite a bunch for forth and back of this. Therefore to me it looks like we need to find a different solution. The strange thing is that people are reporting this problem even without WSO2 installed, which is totally strange to me. It looks like there is only one bundle exporting the maven runtime, but the error still appears.
Looks great, thanks for this fix. Merged into master.

This looks like a network issue or stale data in the p2 cache used by Eclipse/STS. Please try to delete the p2/org.eclipse.equinox.p2.repository/cache directory and try again. Another option would be to change the URL of the STS update site in the preferences from "download.springsource.com" to "dist.springsource.com" and try again. Hope this helps!
Thanks for the feedback and for letting us know. Will close this.

This might be related to: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=427148. So hopefully this is fixed in the latest releases of Eclipse. Please start with a fresh STS 3.6.4 installation (based on Luna SR2) and keep an eye on this so see if this happens again in the future, ok? If so, we can re-open this issue here.
What happens if you change the URL of the update site from "http://dist.springsource.com..." to "http://download.springsource.com..."? Or did you change this already in the past?

Usually the correct Eclipse update site should already be configured in your Eclipse/STS installation. You don't need to add a new one. It could be quite dangerous to add the Eclipse Luna update site to an STS installation that runs on Eclipse 4.3, for example. Your description @ronatartifact sounds a bit like this is what you tried.

If you would like to update to a new STS version, keep the Eclipse update site the same as before and run a "check for updates". If that fails for whatever reason, feel free to cleanup the cache and change the STS update site as described above. If that still fails, I would recommend to download a fresh copy of STS which is based on the latest Eclipse release and go from there.

Hope this helps!

I am sorry to hear that you are having so much trouble and would love to help you. I checked the mentioned two repo locations and there is indeed no p2 update repository found at those locations. But I wonder where they are coming from. You should not need to add additional update sites to STS as long as you don't have additional third-pary plugins installed.

I would also use your existing workspace with a fresh copy of STS to avoid the hassle of setting up all the various settings and preferences again.

Are there concrete steps that you can send me to reproduce issues on my end?

If you install a fresh copy of STS (by downloading the ZIP file of the distribution and unpack it) and use a fresh and clean workspace, you are loosing third-party plug-in history. There should be nothing added to the installation automatically and settings should be clean as well.

The settings storage for Eclipse/STS question is difficult to answer, since not all plug-ins store their settings in the same area. A lot of settings are stored in the <yourworkspace>/.metadata/.plugins area. Maybe you can find the settings that you are looking for in there.
Glad to hear that you got everything back to work and sorry again for the trouble you had with upgrading to the new version. Hope this is a lot smoother next time.

Hey! The update site is available via http://dist.springframework.org/snapshot/IDE/nightly/, you might have caught an intermediate state where the build was deleting the old content before uploading the new one. I checked the content a minute ago and it looks fine.

The other update site that you mentioned belongs to the distribution and contains a lot more stuff than the Spring IDE project specific update site (and is updated less frequently). Therefore I would like to keep the readme as it is and not change it to the big distribution product update site. Hope this is fine with you.

The best way to work on individual Spring IDE pieces is to clone the Git repository, run STS, and import the projects you wanna work on. I would not go ahead and import all the various projects, just those you would like to modify, run, debug.

The PDE in Eclipse (the plugin development environment) usually takes care of resolving the dependencies of those plugins against your target platform, which is your running STS by default. This is the most convenient way.

If you have changed your code, you can start a "runtime workbench", so you don't start anything as "Java application", but instead you go to the launch configurations in Eclipse and create a new launch "Eclipse application" configuration. If you run that, it starts up another Eclipse/STS instance and includes the plugin projects that you have in your workspace. You can start to test/debug your plugin that way.

Hope this helps. If you wanna know/learn more about developing plugins for Eclipse, there are tons of tutorials and books about this out there. Working on STS plugins is no different than that. But it is very different from working on standard Java apps.

I tried this myself a minute ago and it works just fine. So lets see what is different in your setup. Can you take a look at the Error Log view in your runtime workbench? I can see a bunch of errors in there (from the screenshot), but I can't see any details.

Running STS on JDK7 causes the other errors that you mentioned, but those are fine. STS can run on JDK7 as well as JDK8, but some features are disabled on JDK7, that is why you are seeing those additional errors.

The main thing that worries me is:
java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.springframework.ide.eclipse.roo.ui.internal.listener.RooEarlyStartup cannot be found by org.springframework.ide.eclipse.roo.ui_3.7.0.qualifier

This means the Roo plugin is somehow there, but classes weren't loaded from it. Can you check the launch configuration and make sure that you have the Roo plugins from your workspace enabled (in the "plugins" tab), but not the Roo plugins from your target environment? (guessing that you have the Roo support installed into your STS that you are working with)

If that doesn't work, me might need to dig a bit deeper, maybe do a screen sharing session to solve this. What do you think?

Great to hear that you got it working. I wasn't expecting the "Maven Plugin" to work (I would have recommended the "Import as existing project...", but if the maven plugin import worked, that is great.

The implementation of the Roo support in the Spring IDE is a bit tricky behind the scenes, so be prepared to dive into some OSGi weirdness. As far as I know it is running an Apache Felix OSGi runtime embedded inside the Roo plugin (and therefore the running Eclipse instance) to startup the Spring Roo runtime. But I hope this doesn't cause too much confusion. Let me know if you have any more questions. Happy to help!

Thanks for incorporating my comments, merged the pull request. Please keep an eye on the builds:
- https://build.spring.io/browse/IDE-E43
- https://build.spring.io/browse/IDE-CONTINUOUSTESTING

There are two options:

1.)
The Spring IDE build at https://build.spring.io/browse/IDE-E43 runs immediately after each push. It uploads the results to the Spring IDE nightly update site (http://dist.springframework.org/snapshot/IDE/nightly/). You can update an existing STS with those newer Spring IDE components by going to the "Install New Software" dialog, selecting the Spring IDE nightly update site, selecting the already installed components of Spring IDE, and press "Install". Eclipse/STS will notify you that the installation got changed automatically from installing new components to updating existing components.

2.)
The second option is to download a nightly distribution build of STS (http://dist.springsource.com/snapshot/STS/nightly-distributions.html) and to install the components you want to test in there manually via "Install New Software" or if they are already installed via "Check for Updates". So in your case, if you have an existing STS nightly build with Roo support installed into it, you should be able to add the nightly distribution update site (http://dist.springsource.com/snapshot/TOOLS/nightly/e4.4 for Eclipse 4.4, for example) and press "Check for Updates". This should do it. The nightly distribution download and update site is built once a day, so it might take a while until changes to Spring IDE are showing up in this distribution build. You can verify that your changes are in that build by downloading it and checking the version of the Spring IDE bundles in your plugins folder. The name contains the exact CI build number from https://build.spring.io/browse/IDE-DNE44.

Hope this helps!!!

One more comment: it is great to see you working on the STS and Eclipse integration for Spring Roo. To make your life easier in the future, it would also be possible to extract the STS Roo plugins into a separate GitHub repository (your own, a DISID organization repo, or something like that) with full commit rights for you. That way you could setup your own Maven tycho build for just those bundles, release them whenever it makes sense to you, and the STS team would consume the latest release from your update site for inclusion in the STS distribution update site and the STS dashboard. Just a thought. Let me know what you think about that. We can also chat about it offline.

I vaguely remember an issue with multiple Roo projects being open in a Roo shell in STS (even though each shell is spinning up its own Felix runtime as far as I remember). I am not sure whether the project-specific cache name was related to that or not, but it would be great if you could check that (if you haven't already) to make sure multiple open Roo shells work nicely.

As another option we could also move just the Roo related parts of the Spring IDE project in GitHub to a separate repository under the same organization (spring-projects) to give you more freedom. But that is just an option. We can also just continue in the same way as we do at the moment.

A side effect of this would be that the Roo plugins for Spring IDE would continue to be included in our milestone/release cycles/builds and that we would change version numbers to match the general Spring IDE process. Is that fine with you? You would also need to be aware of the release build/test/GA dates and work towards them as well. What do you think?

Hmmm, this looks very specific to Ubuntu. Which version of Ubuntu are you using? The Eclipse support for Linux GTK is somewhat fragile with regards to the version of Linux and specifically the version of Ubuntu that is being used. Can you also try to run pure Eclipse (just to verify that this is a problem with the Eclipse Linux support)? And maybe also try one of the latest Eclipse Oxygen builds from the downloads? Maybe that is something that got fixed in the meantime.

You could also try to switch back to the GTK2 support (which isn't better in general, but might not have that specific issue that you came across): https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=430736#c50
Thanks for the pull request. Much appreciated!!!
Glad to hear that you found the reason for the issue and thanks for letting us know.
If you add a new file, you should have your company mentioned as the copyright owner, not "GoPivotal, Inc." (in case it is truely new, not copied).
No problem at all, thanks a lot for YOUR work on the Roo support and your pull requests!!!
Ok, I will close this for now. If you come across the same situation, please comment and we will re-open this issue. Thanks a lot for your help!!!
Yes, this is a temporary outage of our nightly CI builds. We hope to get those update sites back online soon. Will update you here as soon as the site is back again.
We are sorry for the inconvenience.
I hope to have the CI builds back sometime today, working on them at the moment.
The nightly Spring IDE repository is back online. Sorry again for the inconvenience!!!

Hey Dominik, thanks for filing this issue, much appreciated. Makes absolutely sense to add this to the tooling. I am wondering why the boot dashboard doesn't show those request mappings (since they are retrieved from the running app and not inferred from the source code), but we will have to investigate this.

Will put that into our tracker for the 3.9.0 release, since we will not be able to squeeze that into the 3.8.4 release anymore. Sorry for that.

This is a duplicate of https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4431 and already fixed for the upcoming 3.8.4 release. Therefore closing this one here. Thanks for reporting and attaching the thread dump. That made it a lot easier to figure out what problem this is. Thanks!!!

I think he mentioned three different places in his comment above, differentiating the spring explorer from the boot dash props view. Anyhow, need to investigate. @dominik42 if you have a sample project that illustrates the problem, feel free to attach. Always helps!!!
This is often caused by stale cache data. If so, it usually helps to remove the update site from the preferences (available update sites), restart STS, and add the update site back.

Hmmm... I really wonder why removing the Neon update site made the STS update to work. The error talks clearly about the STS artifacts not being found and they are not related to the Neon update site at all. The p2 magic under the hood is a mystery from time to time. Anyhow, you solved it and I am very glad to hear that you got it working.

And maybe your finding helps other having the same issue. Thanks for all the details that you posted here. Much appreciated.
(this got migrated from https://jira.spring.io/browse/IDE-1391)

In case you are looking for more details regarding the Spring Boot dashboard in STS, take a look at this introductory blog entry: https://spring.io/blog/2015/10/08/the-spring-boot-dashboard-in-sts-part-1-local-boot-apps

The reason that this happen is because:

Whenever you set a breakpoint in Eclipse/STS, the IDE tries to set the breakpoint in the VM if you launch an app. That is what happens in your case when you run the boot app in debug mode.

For each class that gets loaded into the JVM, the IDE checks whether it needs to set a breakpoint or not. If it decides to set the breakpoint, the tries to do so (using the information from the breakpoint definition in the IDE, including its line number, since you usually set line breakpoints on a source file at a given line).

This decision (whether to set the breakpoint on a given loaded class or not) checks the types that you set the breakpoint on, enclosing types, and inner classes. This makes sure that breakpoints for inner classes (even anonymous inner classes) are set to the JVM (and are not ignored).

Spring Boot generates an inner class for your controller at runtime (this is the CGLIB generated inner class that appears in the error message). When the JVM loads that class, it tries to set the line number breakpoint of the enclosing type (for this inner class). Since the generated inner class doesn't have any line number information (it doesn't need to have line number information), setting the breakpoint fails for this inner class with the mentioned error message.

When the IDE loads the enclosing type (your controller class itself), it also tries to set the line breakpoint and succeeds with that. This is visualized with the check marker on the breakpoint marker.

Therefore you can safely ignore the error message that shows up. To avoid this error message to show up, you can go to the preferences (Java -> Debug) and disable "Warn when unable to install breakpoint due to missing line number attributes".
And thanks for pointing me to the other issue and the sample project, I was able to use that to debug into all the details here. Thanks again for that pointer, much appreciated!!!

I am not all in favor of setting too many config options by default for our users, so I am not sure about this one. Let people comment here if they think this option should be disabled by default for all our users and we can do that.

I think adding some keystrokes is a good idea and we had this on the list for the dashboard already quite a while ago. However, there are two questions: which keystrokes to choose (to avoid collisions with other keystrokes) and should they take the selected project in the boot dashboard into account (and start/stop/restart those) or do you think about the one that belongs to the current open editor? Or maybe both, depending on the active part in your UI?

Since we use regular launch configs for running Spring Boot apps, you can use the same keystrokes to start and also re-start a spring boot app (in the same way it works for regular Java apps in Eclipse/STS). So the only missing piece would be the STOP operation.

Just to understand this in more detail: don't those regular keystrokes to start/restart apps work for you for your boot apps? Or would you like to have separate ones to differentiate between regular apps and boot apps?

I would guess that this is related to bundle wiring dependency issues around certain Maven packages. Since we implemented a few changes in this area, I would like to ask you to check the latest Eclipse Neon release and try to install the latest Spring Tool Suite components into that (you could use the Marketplace, if you would like to give that a try). The versions for Eclipse Luna are out-of-date and not updated with newer versions of STS anymore.

It sounds like the update to the CI version left you with an installation that contains multiple versions of the tooling at the same time. Which version of STS did you have before? Something installed into Eclipse? Or the STS distro? And which version of those?
Great, good catch. Thanks for the pull request, much appreciated!!!

You are completely right, I tried this myself and it is indeed the case. This is also the case when you use the latest STS distribution download (3.8.4), so there must be a left-over from some refactoring in the extension definitions. Thats for finding that out. I think I usually use the context-menu in the Spring perspective (where this duplicate doesn't appear) instead of the general "New ->" menu... ;-)

You can find the MD5 for that file here: http://download.springsource.com/release/STS/3.8.4.RELEASE/dist/e4.6/spring-tool-suite-3.8.4.RELEASE-e4.6.3-win32-x86_64.zip.md5

Which file is corrupted in your case? A maven jar file?
In case something in your local Maven repository is corrupted (which seem to happen quite frequently), I would recommend to delete the local maven repository and import the project again. Just in case...

The md5 and sha1 files are always available for every release, but we don't add links to those files on the download page to reduce space on the page and make the page less crowded. But you are right, it is hard to find them if you don't know where they are. We should at least provide a hint that md5 and sha1 checksums can be found under the same download URL + ".md5" and ".sha1".
Yepp, I filed an issue for the website project to include those links again. Makes sense. Thanks for the feedback.

The issue that you refer to is related to having the Groovy-Eclipse extension installed. Is that the case in your installation?

The error that you mention does indeed look like an incompatibility between plugins and/or patched JDT versions. Can you check which plugins you have installed (and their versions)? Especially the Groovy-Eclipse plugins and the Spring IDE plugins?

Also a full stack trace would be useful to see exactly where this problem happens. You can (hopefully) find it in the Error Log view.

Ah, that could be the problem, indeed. Version 3.8.4 refers to the STS component and not Eclipse, correct. But I think it is time to retire the old 2.9.2 release item altogether from the marketplace, before it creates more confusion for more people. Sorry for that. Ok to close this item now?

We sync this with our pivotal tracker instance, so "delivered" means that the associated story got implemented and is ready for acceptance in tracker. Code is committed to the repo and a snapshot build of this is available from the project-specific p2 update site... :-)

The log file contains quite a number of bundle resolve issues around package use constraints, so something seems to be seriously broken with the installation. This might be caused by an update or an install of additional bundles, hard to say what exactly caused this.

I would recommend to try a fresh and clean STS 3.8.4 distribution build from https://spring.io/tools, first of all just to see if that makes a difference and how that behaves in your environment. You don't need to recreate the workspace, please go ahead and re-use your existing workspace when you startup the freshly installed STS distro, so that settings aren't lost, and let us know how that behaves.

Depending on the exact message, I don't think that this is related to the VM setting in the sts.ini file. If this is the macOS dialog popping up, did you try to add something like this to the Info.plist file? https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/95582/1/features/org.eclipse.equinox.executable.feature/bin/cocoa/macosx/x86_64/Eclipse.app/Contents/Info.plist

You can try that (and also run STS with "-clean" option, that might help, too), but I can't give you a definite answer. Those package use constraint issues are a hard-to-resolve issue. But you can go back step by step through the installation (via the About -> Installation Details) and see if that makes a difference.

Installing a fresh STS 3.8.4 distribution build might be the easier way though.

Thanks for the report, looks like one of those bad dependency issues... :-(
Can you provide a few steps how to reproduce this?
And can you try to start STS (or Eclipse) with the "-clean" option, just to see if that makes a difference?

@martin3361 I analyzed your error details in more detail and I can see now why this problem appears. It is a deep-down dependency issue, which is caused by the com.google.guava bundle being installed in two different versions. I don't know exactly how the never version 21 got into your install, but it is causing the issue. I will try to dive deeper to see how I can prevent this issue.
@rue-jw The problem after installing Groovy-Eclipse and switching to the 2.4 compiler is a different problem, also causing many other Spring views to fail. Please open a separate issue for that.

@rue-jw I created a separate issue for the Groovy-Eclipse problem:
https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/issues/151
this also looks similar to the error message in #151 , although the setting seems to be different.
@martin3361 would be great if you could give these snapshots build a try and let us know if that fixes the issue on your end.

issues.title: Strange 'please install Java 6 Legacy' dialog on Mac OS
issues.body:
Greg Turnquist experienced this. I wonder if there's something wrong with the Mac Os packaging. 

I found a bug in Eclipse bugzilla that looks like the same problem. But the Eclipse folks did something to fix it. Maybe STS, doesn't have that Mac OS, packaging fix?

https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=475640

These are the bits of info I know about Greg's problem / setup.

- installed Java 8 via 'sdkman'.
- added the -vm to front of STS.ini to use the Java 8 vm from sdkman
- installed STS into 'Applications' folder on Mac.
- tried moving it somewhere else but it didn't help.

issues.title: Suggest disabling healthcheck when starting app in debug mode on cf
issues.body: Like when we start an app with devtools, it would make sense also for an app started in debug mode via ssh tunnelling. Breakpoints tend to screw up timing and cause apps to be killed when health-check is enabled.

commits.message: Support for parsing changed requestmapping data for Boot 2.0 actuator
Another attempt to fix Eclipse 4.6 / 4.7 / 4.8 api compat around HtmlPrinter
Fix compilation errors against Eclipse 4.8 HtmlPrinter api
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:SpringSource/spring-ide
Add a basic mechanism to enable boot validation builder on boot projects
Fix beans parser for changes in Boot 2.0 format
Cleanups: delete some obsolete comments, fix som comment spelling

Tweaks to props -> yaml conversion:

Safer special type handling so that quotes are still added if the toString
value would otherwise change.

This gets rid of the quotes in most cases but doesn't risk some accidental
conversion of a string value into something else because it coincidentally looked
like a number.
Avoid adding quotes around certain types of values in props -> yml conversion

Fix PT-154181609

Convert .properties to .yml uses active editor as target even if 
invoked from a menu which makes a selection in the package explorer (or
other tree-viewer). If the active editor is not consistent with the tree viewer
selection this results in applying the conversion to another file than the
one selected by the user.

The fix is to make a more complex logic of determining the refactoring
which takes the 'active menu selection' into account as well.

Fix PT-154061574

Don't repop the dialog to install cloud cli on every restart.
Fix Github Issue #220
Bump timeout of a failing test

Fix some failing tests.

Cause: new local service called 'stubrunner' was added in newer boot/cloud/cli.

Fix Github issue #222:

Immediate editing of classpath for a boot launch conf that was created directly
from Eclipse UI still bypasses our classpath provider, resulting in test deps on the
runtime classpath.
Update thin wrapper version used in test
Add more debug output to failing test
Add falback in synchLaunch for non Boot launches.
Attempt to fix test failures suspected to be caused by test target-platform issue
Improve output from failing test
Fix NPE
Attempt to fix suspected race condition causing test failures
Another try to fix test case
Try to fix a test case
Fix pom issue
Remove duplication of lsp4e / lsp4j update site delcs and update to snapshots
Add version constraint to ensure recent enough lps4j bundle available
Another attempt at updating lspe / lsp4j to snapshots
Use lsp4e snapshot
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:SpringSource/spring-ide

Give Spring Boot Validations Builder a proper name

Otherwise it looks a bit odd when shown in the Eclipse ui.
Self-contained implementation of EnableJDTAptM2EProjectConfigurator
WidgetUtil renamed to SWTConnect
Take advantage of improved highlighting for textbased viewer filter
Searchbox for livebean property page
More debug output for thin launcher test
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:SpringSource/spring-ide
Relax version constraint on jdt.launching bundle

Use MethodHandles to call super 'getClasspathAndModulePath'

So we can compile on older Eclipse API and still override and call super
as required on newer API.

pull_requests.title: Experimental change that makes both stop button and
pull_requests.body:
runstate tracker for local apps based only on processes
associated with the 'blessed' launch config.

Note: not sure yet we want to merge this. Just creating this PR so I can point to it in this discussion in the tracker: https://www.pivotaltracker.com/story/show/104726470

issue_comments.body: Thanks!
If so, then isn't that a bug for devtools to sort out? STS only starts devtools remote client. It doesn't interfere with what the client (or devtools itself) actually does.

Hi Torsten, from what I can tell the problem here seems to be that people are trying to run STS either intentionally or unintentionally on JDK 7 which is simply not supported with the latest version of STS.

Your choices working around this are:

 a) upgrade your jdk to 1.8
 b) stick with old versions of everything, Eclipse / STS / JDK etc. all around.

There is not and will not be a newer version of STS which runs on JDK 7. There simply are too many dependencies on things which are only working on JDK 8 for that to be practical.

We understand that some folks simply can't upgrade, for whatever reason, and of course that choice is yours to make, but you should then stick to installing a old version of STS as well.

> What would stop the dashboard from detecting the application has started?

STS uses a JMX bean to which it connects via a socket to 
 - ask whether app is 'started'
 - ask the app to 'shutdown nicely' (when you click stop button).

So it would seem that STS cannot connect to the JMX bean for some reason.

It could be some firewall or network setting (.e.g: https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-4413)

Or it could be that your app has a more custom configuration than the typical boot app and the JMX bean has not been enabled. I have seen one example of this where a user 'trimmed down' their config and by doing so had removed the JMX admin bean from their app. I was looking for the issue ticket but couldn't find it unfurtunately. 

> The launch config is the one created by the dashboard, nothing changed in it.

What about the app itself? How was that created? If you create one with 'New >> Spring Starter Project' wizard then it should work (barring any funky network / firewall settings that may prohibit local socket connections between STS and the boot app to be established)

A fix has been pushed to master. The fix contributes an extra import strategy for BuildShip version 2.x. The old strategy was kept as well, with some minor changes to label it more appropriately. So now, the wizard's pull-down menu provides separate choices for Buildship 1.x and Buildship 2.x.

The fix is available from snapshot update site: 
https://dist.springframework.org/snapshot/IDE/nightly
I think Dominik isn't talking about boot dash, but the "Spring Explorer" view. I think that uses a bean model that is build more statically from the project contents.

I just tried. Downloaded and installed STS 3.8.3. Then added the STS 3.8.4 update site to 'Available Update Sites': 
http://download.springsource.com/release/TOOLS/update/e4.6

Then I did 'Check for updates' and let it perform the suggested updates.

All went without an issue and a quick smoke-test of the resulting STS seems like it is in working order.

Not sure what might be the problem on your end. These are some guesses:

1. Did you use the correct update site for your version of eclipse platform (e4.5 / e4.6 / e4.7) ? (Probably you are, but worth double-checking).

2. Maybe there's a network issue interferring with downloading the content from the update site(s). This could be a temporary network problem, or something more permanent like proxy/firewalls in your network environment or OS blocking network access. The error message seems to hint at not being able to find any content on the update site. But I just verified that the content is there and working fine.
The spring boot dashboard ui does that doesn't it? If not please elaborate what it is you want, because I don't think I understand.

STS also has a custom (Re)start and stop button in the toolbar. It doesn't do exactly what you want, it starts / stops / restarts the last run process (could be a boot app, or something else).

That is a simple 'one click'. Still not good enough?

I feel like we already have a lot of ways to start/stop and relaunch processes (including boot apps) that are pretty convenient. So I'm bit reluctant to add another one.

I.e. if you are having multiple apps then the Boot Dash UI is for you. If you only have one app, then maybe its not as useful and not worth the extra space, but in that case the 'restart' and 'stop' buttons in the toolbars fit your use-case no?

Maybe we should reopen this ticket and look at overriding the default value of the preference as a proper resolution. That might avoid other people getting confused by this 'harmless' error they should just ignore.

>  once and should work out of the box, based on m2e detection of spring boot deps, shouldn't it?

Yes. 

Do you have a sample project available? It works for the projects I've tried. So I'll need your specific example to debug the nature of the problem.
Okay great! Thanks! I'll close this ticket now as the problem is m2e not STS.

> so you would need to be able to select a jar that has them

I guess that is really the most crucial point. So the question, select the jar from where? Just a location on the user's hard-drive?

Okay, great. So basically a way to select jar via maven coordinates and specify a launcher class (maybe with some magics in the UI to limit the choices to main types that actually exist in the selected jar). You are right that doesn't sound too difficulty. 

I guess the part that seemed confusing to me, and so probably also other 'naive' users would be around knowing what jars they can actually use here, and where to find them, and the main classes in them.

Perhaps it would make most sense if we make this part easy for the user by curating a list of choices for them. E.g. there's some kind of pull-down with pre-populated list of 'launcher jars' they can choose from. Maybe we can also provide a 'type whatever you want' option for the experts. 

If we go with a curated list, the question is, who maintains that list, and how does STS find it. Do we just bake the list into STS? If so, how does STS team keep it up-to date when you guys make changes / fixes / new launchers.

I also have some potential confusion around the classpath given to the launcher. I presume in production, it would not have the actual jars from the project's dependencies itself on the classpath when launching the launcher, since, essentially, the launcher is the one responsible for setting up the classpath. So as such, I gather that *adding* the jar to your classpath isn't entirely faithfull to how it would work in production. Not sure whether this really matters or not. 

Finally I also wondered/worried about the 'packaging' since it seems the launcher stuff, like the thin launcher for example, consists a component to 'package' things and then also launcher thing that knows the packaging layout and uses that to setup a classpath for the boot app to run. It seems our 'simulation' here (picking a launcher jar + main type) only accounts for the launching stage and is implicitly assuming that pointing it at the eclipse-computed classpath instead of the 'real' packaging, is going to be okay for the launcher. If that's always true, regardless of the launcher/packager, then maybe I'm worried over nothing.

issues.title: Define Spring Boot shortcuts to start, restart, stop etc.
issues.body: I am pretty sure it is common that managing Spring Boot application with one click would be productive improvement. Usually, I work with single Spring Boot application, but the shortcut for last used Spring Boot application is simplified solution.

issue_comments.body: I am talking about keystrokes as shortcuts to start/restart/stop spring boot application. For example, Crtl+Alt+F9 keystroke starts last used Spring Boot application, Ctrl+Alt+F10 restarts and Ctrl+Alt+F11 stops, something simple.

I am thinking something like align with existing Eclipse experience; we can add configuration in "Preference > Spring > Boot", which gives selection of "Always launch the previously launched application" and "Launch selected resource or active editor" similar the one in "Preference > Run/Debug > Launching".

For keystroke decision, agreed, we need to find available.

issues.title: Spring-Tool-Suite is validating project twice
issues.body:
The IDE version is 3.8.1.RELEASE , Build Id: 201607290850 , Platform: Eclipse Neon (4.6)

The system is Windows7 64-bit

Here is the scenario which makes the bug happens : 

- I clean the Pivotal server by clicking the context-menu option "Clean tc Server Work Directory" of the server

- I clean the Pivotal server by clicking the context-menu option "Clean..." of the server

- I clean the project , and I check the checkbox "Start a build immediately".

So after clicking the OK button then the project is validated. When this validation reaches 100% then the same project is validated again !
[suivi_evaluation.zip](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/files/566259/suivi_evaluation.zip)

issues.title: Devtools with CF: new class doesn't get included
issues.body: I'm not sure if this is supposed to work or not, but it would be useful if it did. What I see is that when I add a new class the app restarts but the new class is not included (so it probably wasn't even uploaded).

issue_comments.body: I guess you know better than I do.
Those low hanging ones are pretty easy for users to do themselves, but if we do it, they will have a better experience without knowing the details. So that sounds like a good first step.

I was working here: https://github.com/dsyer/spring-cloud-function/blob/feature/catalog/spring-cloud-function-context/src/main/java/org/springframework/cloud/function/context/ContextFunctionCatalogAutoConfiguration.java. I have 3.8.3 with Groovy tooling added from the STS dashboard, plus YK and JDepend.
Thanks for the info. I already had that update site. I pulled the latest from there and the problem doesn't go away.
[threads.txt](https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ide/files/792843/threads.txt)
I haven't, sorry, and of course it's not behaving the same way now. I can still get the data if you want?

The `ThinJarWrapper` can be downloaded in its own jar (you don't have to unpack it from another one): e.g. http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/springframework/boot/experimental/spring-boot-thin-wrapper/1.0.2.RELEASE/. Ditto the `PropertiesLauncher`. The best way for a user to locate these would be via maven co-ordinates.

I can simulate what I want STS to do here by simply adding a dependency to the POM and changing the Java main class in the launch configuration. So it doesn't seem really very complicated or specially crafted for the thin launcher. Just inconvenient and fiddly to do manually.

> If we go with a curated list, the question is, who maintains that list, and how does STS find it.

We could stick it in spring.io or start.spring.io I guess, or you could scrape the versions from Maven Central. An expert option where the user can change co-ordinates would be good too.

> So as such, I gather that adding the jar to your classpath isn't entirely faithfull to how it would work in production. Not sure whether this really matters or not.

Correct. I think it probably does matter (so my simulation where I got it working isn't perfect), but we will only find out how much by doing it.

> implicitly assuming that pointing it at the eclipse-computed classpath instead of the 'real' packaging, is going to be okay for the launcher

Yeah, specifically we probably need to modify that classpath. At least to remove all the jar files. And let the user specify through system properties or command line arguments how to locate them again.

commit_comments.body: Why would you make this change and require all consumers of the this public API to change? Why not allow 2 getConfig() methods (getConfig(String) and getConfig(IFile)) instead. The old getConfig(IFile) could delegate internally to getConfig(String). That way you safe a lot of changes and don't break existing consumers of the API.

Hi Martin,

Thanks for your comments. Following your recommendations I've apply the following changes:
- We need to be able to share cache folder between projects because using Spring Roo 2.0+ you could customize your distribution dynamically... To solve this problem:
  - Roo STS Plugin only shares cache folder with every generated project when Spring Roo 2.0+ distribution is used. 
  - Spring Roo 2.0+ will include "felix.cache.locking=false" on conf/config.properties to allow share cache folder

I've tested the changes above and now I'm able to open multiple Spring Roo Shells without any problem using 2.0+ and 1.x . (https://issuetracker.springsource.com/browse/STS-2607)
- Project creation command has changed on Spring Roo 2.0+, so we need to be able to work with Spring Roo 1.x distributions and Spring Roo 2.0+ distributions. To solve it:
  - When Spring Roo 2.0+ is present, I've add a new instruction on project creation command.

If you have more comments about this changes, let me know!!

Regards,

Fedora and RHEL7.2 ship their own version of javax.servlet in an RPM, which conflicts with the one in Orbit because they have different Bundle-SymbolicName values (javax.servlet vs. javax.servlet-api). Solution is to not depend on a BUNDLE, but on a PACKAGE (or packages). 

Details in https://jira.spring.io/browse/IDE-1393 and https://issues.jboss.org/browse/JBDS-4190

I don't think it makes sense anymore to treat exceptions that happen while building the beans model as real errors. Especially in the new versions of Spring and Spring Boot, there are numerous situations where creating bean definitions for the beans model involves executing code of conditional annotations, properties, etc. All stuff that doesn't really exist while coding in the IDE.

Therefore I decided to log those issues as warnings instead of errors in the Error Log view.

(comment in Pivotal Tracker added by Martin Lippert:) 

It looks like the build is re-creating the beans model behind the scenes and is doing that work while you observe the 1-2min pause.

I wonder why it takes so long to create that model and would love to find out that takes so long. Can you run YourKit, attach a profiler to the IDE process, and record a CPU profiling (optimal would be in "Tracing" mode). Would be really interesting to see that data.

In addition to that you could avoid this by removing the Spring nature from the project. Then the model isn't created anymore and your build should be back to normal.

I did a little digging into how the 'thin jar launcher/wrapper' works. So in that case  the main type is called 'ThinJarWrapper'. To get a jar that can be placed on classpath so this type can be launched we need to do this:

1. Donwload or find this jar: /.m2/repository/org/springframework/boot/experimental/spring-boot-thin-layout/1.0.2.RELEASE/spring-boot-thin-layout-1.0.2.RELEASE.jar

2. Inside that jar pull-out the nested jar at  `/metainf/loader/spring-boot-thin-wrapper.jar`

This is the jar that actually contains the `ThinJarWrapper` class.  It seems rather unlikely a user will have this jar sitting by itself on his hard-drive. So a UI that makes the user point to a jar sitting on his filesystem probably isn't all that useful (as getting the jar will be a cumbersome process).

So... I can imagine that we implement something which is rather specific to the ThinJarLauncher and so STS would know exactly where to download the jar, extract the nested jar, and put that on the classpath when launching, but such a solution willnot  be very generally re-usable, it will *only* work for the ThinJarLauncher case.

Is that really what we are after here?

(comment in Pivotal Tracker added by Martin Lippert:) 

I also took a closer look at this. It seems that the core Groovy bundle is calling "refreshPackages" on the OSGi package admin at some time during startup, to set the specified Groovy compiler bundle.

The package admin service is deprecated some quite some time. And I think it is quite dangerous to trigger the OSGi runtime to refresh packages during Eclipse startup. I think it is dangerous at all in an Eclipse IDE environment, since it is not built to be as dynamic as the OSGi runtime suggests it is.

I don't know enough about the Groovy compiler settings (and how all that works), but this piece looks dangerous.

(comment in Pivotal Tracker added by Martin Lippert:) 

I think the problematic piece starts here:
https://github.com/groovy/groovy-eclipse/blob/5bdf7b3dfdd31492dd4f844d3cc82282f4cf5c53/base/org.codehaus.groovy.eclipse.compilerResolver/src/org/codehaus/groovy/frameworkadapter/util/CompilerChooser.java#L123

(comment in Pivotal Tracker added by Martin Lippert:) 

If I understand the underlying logic correctly, a compiler switch uninstalls all the other compiler bundles and triggers the runtime to restart and to re-resolve bundles, so that other components get wired to the selected compiler bundle.

If that is correct, I would suggest to install/uninstall the bundles and then trigger a restart with "-clean". That should do everything that is needed. It should not be necessary to do anything else during startup.

Another option would be to define version constraints in the importing bundle and use a framework hook to specify that version range exactly to the version you selected at startup - and let the OSGi resolver do the rest. That way you would not need to install/uninstall bundles or re-wire packages or do anything dynamic (like refreshPackages) during startup.

To answer your question, what do we do now; well we use OEPE based on "Kepler" which has the Oracle plugin. First we generate e.g. 10K lines of code with JPA Entity to Class plugin. Then we migrate JPA config xml to new version of JPA. Then we use the Oracle tool to generate spring services based on classes generated earlier. 

To answer other question: why don't we ask Oracle to update tool, shortly, based on the experience, it wouldn't happen, Oracle proposed using abstract DAO pattern which doesn't contribute reducing size spring service code.

Thanks for moving topic here. If one day it gets solved it would be great.

After upgrade to 3.8.4.RELEASE the situation is slightly different:
* `<Spring Boot Project>` / Spring Tools / Show RequestMappings
The request mappings annotated with the new annotation are not show, the other are shown
* Spring Explorer View / `<Spring Boot Project>` / Beans / Request Mapping

Update: I think I have found why I have this problem.

I installed STS from the Eclipse Marketplace. There, you have 2 versions of STS : one for Eclipse Helios (3.6), the other for Eclipse, but this version is labelled "STS for Eclipse 3.8.4 RELEASE", so I thought the "3.8.4" was related to Eclipse, but in fact it isn't: it is the STS version.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/28762009/26203638/4f1cfcf0-3bdc-11e7-996b-81d5a27082be.png)


So I installed the wrong version of STS, leading to all these bugs.

Yes, this ticket should be closed.

It is not a bug. I uninstalled previous version of STS and groovy, and installed latest version of STS and everything is running fine.

Thanks !

Starting with another clean workspace restores spring views, but also restores the Groovy compiler version to the default.
Uninstalling all Groovy-Eclipse stuff does restore functionality.

Did you enable "Spring Nature" on the project?

For historical reasons, some of the original SI schemas on the internet are outdated; we can't change them without possibly breaking (admittedly very old) user applications.

See the `IMPORTANT` note near the top of [this one](http://www.springframework.org/schema/integration/spring-integration.xsd).

If you enable Spring Nature on the project, STS knows how to find the proper schema in the spring jars (there is special mapping in `META-INF/spring.schemas`).
